channel.title: Scientific American - Latest Issue
channel.description: Latest articles from Scientific American magazine

item.title: The incredible, unlikely story of how cats became our pets
item.description: Two new studies dig into the long, curving path that cats took toward domestication
item.dc:creator: Meghan Bartels
item.author: Meghan Bartels
item.guid: The incredible, unlikely story of how cats became our pets

item.title: These birds learned to tweet like R2-D2. Listen to the uncanny results
item.description: This lovable Star Wars droid is helping to shed light on why some bird species are better at mimicking sounds than others
item.dc:creator: Kate Graham-Shaw
item.author: Kate Graham-Shaw
item.guid: These birds learned to tweet like R2-D2. Listen to the uncanny results

item.title: Spiders build giant decoys to scare predators from webs
item.description: Spiders scare off predators by seemingly supersizing themselves
item.dc:creator: Gennaro Tomma
item.author: Gennaro Tomma
item.guid: Spiders build giant decoys to scare predators from webs

item.title: Zoo lunch mishap reveals lizards’ hidden fire detector
item.description: Australian “sleepy” lizards are not so sleepy when it comes to fire
item.dc:creator: Clarissa Brincat
item.author: Clarissa Brincat
item.guid: Zoo lunch mishap reveals lizards’ hidden fire detector

item.title: Lost planet Theia, which created the moon, came from the inner solar system
item.description: New work pinpoints the origins of the planet Theia, whose ancient collision with Earth likely produced the moon
item.dc:creator: Jacek Krywko
item.author: Jacek Krywko
item.guid: Lost planet Theia, which created the moon, came from the inner solar system

item.title: Not everyone with schizophrenia hears voices. Here’s why
item.description: New research aims to tease out what exactly is happening in the brains of people with schizophrenia who have auditory hallucinations
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seo
item.author: Hannah Seo
item.guid: Not everyone with schizophrenia hears voices. Here’s why

item.title: How woodpeckers turn their entire bodies into pecking machines
item.description: These birds’ drilling approach is more like extreme tennis playing than weight lifting
item.dc:creator: Rohini Subrahmanyam
item.author: Rohini Subrahmanyam
item.guid: How woodpeckers turn their entire bodies into pecking machines

item.title: Why 52 cards is the perfect number for poker—mathematically
item.description: A traditional card deck happens to dodge a tricky poker paradox. Other poker variants aren’t so lucky
item.dc:creator: Emma R. Hasson
item.author: Emma R. Hasson
item.guid: Why 52 cards is the perfect number for poker—mathematically

item.title: Math puzzle: A winning loser
item.description: Pick an unusual winning poker hand in this math puzzle

item.author: Emma R. Hasson
item.guid: Math puzzle: A winning loser

item.title: This fossil is rewriting the story of how plants spread across the planet
item.description: An enigmatic group of fossil organisms has finally been identified—and is changing the story of how plants took root on land
item.dc:creator: Taylor Mitchell Brown
item.author: Taylor Mitchell Brown
item.guid: This fossil is rewriting the story of how plants spread across the planet

item.title: Why does life keep evolving these geometric patterns?
item.description: A global catalog shows how creatures across the tree of life balance rigidity with flexibility in remarkably consistent ways
item.dc:creator: Anirban Mukhopadhyay
item.author: Anirban Mukhopadhyay
item.guid: Why does life keep evolving these geometric patterns?

item.title: Extremophile ‘fire amoeba’ pushes the boundaries of complex life
item.description: It was thought that complex cells couldn’t survive above a certain temperature, but a tiny amoeba has proven that assumption wrong
item.dc:creator: Andrea Thompson
item.author: Andrea Thompson
item.guid: Extremophile ‘fire amoeba’ pushes the boundaries of complex life

item.title: A bright light in the dark
item.description: The Nobel Prizes remind us how science can unite society and inspire hope for the future
item.dc:creator: David M. Ewalt
item.author: David M. Ewalt

item.title: Readers respond to the October 2025 issue

item.title: How one mom used vibe coding to build an AI tutor for her dyslexic son
item.description: Faced with her son’s struggle with dyslexia, one mom built an AI platform to help kids learn their own way
item.dc:creator: Deni Ellis Béchard
item.author: Deni Ellis Béchard
item.guid: How one mom used vibe coding to build an AI tutor for her dyslexic son

item.title: The neuroscience behind the ‘parenting paradox’ of happiness
item.description: Separate brain processes cope with moment-to-moment versus big-picture experiences, which helps to explain how parenting both increases and decreases aspects of well-being
item.dc:creator: Anthony Vaccaro
item.author: Anthony Vaccaro
item.guid: The neuroscience behind the ‘parenting paradox’ of happiness

item.title: The math mystery that connects Sudoku, flight schedules and protein folding
item.description: Thousands of notoriously difficult problems in computer science are actually the same problem in disguise
item.dc:creator: Jack Murtagh
item.author: Jack Murtagh
item.guid: The math mystery that connects Sudoku, flight schedules and protein folding

item.title: Why is the Milky Way warped?
item.description: Observations show the disk of our galaxy is not flat but warped and waving. Astronomers are still working out the reasons why
item.dc:creator: Phil Plait
item.author: Phil Plait
item.guid: Why is the Milky Way warped?

item.title: Heal injuries faster with new science
item.description: Motion is the new potion, and rest is no longer the best

item.title: History smelled. Here’s how we’re sniffing it out

item.title: Which dog breed stereotypes are true? Here’s the science

item.title: What is consciousness? Science faces its hardest problem yet

item.title: JWST could finally spot the very first stars in the universe

item.title: Life’s evil twins—mirror cells—could doom Earth if scientists don’t stop them

item.title: How extremophile molds are destroying museum artifacts
item.description: Extremophile molds are invading art museums and devouring their collections. Stigma and climate change have fueled their spread

item.title: Can a buried time capsule beat Earth’s geology and deep time?
item.description: A ridiculous but instructive thought experiment involving deep time, plate tectonics, erosion and the slow death of the sun
